Topic.Title: What is Icera i500 “soft” modem or in long form, a Software Defined Radio (SDR)?

Message.Msg: Doing a side by side comparison is hard to do because the underlying architectures are fundamentally different with little or no commonalities. There are efficiencies to be had or must in either solutions that can impact the comparison either way. From a pure theoretical standpoint anytime you add layers of abstraction (SDR) you are potentially adding inefficiencies. However, a good software design can outperform a poor ASIC's design. Now that being said I think the real question is not which one is better by comparing raw numbers but how negligible can you make the perceptions of those inefficiencies from one solution to another. Thus there is no reason good engineers can't overcome these problems and provide a solution that is perceived to be as good as a good hardware solution or even better than a less efficient HW solution.

Topic.Title: What is Icera i500 “soft” modem or in long form, a Software Defined Radio (SDR)?

Message.Msg: You are so annoying ...

Topic.Title: What is Icera i500 “soft” modem or in long form, a Software Defined Radio (SDR)?

Message.Msg: The main advantage of a soft modem is the ability to change it fast as specs evolve. It also saves on power and cost.

Topic.Title: What is Icera i500 “soft” modem or in long form, a Software Defined Radio (SDR)?

Message.Msg: Cost and flexibility are both advantages but that wasn't the question posed. The question was how do the compare bit for bit. Also, power isn't an innate advantage - not to say that it can't be by it's not by definition. I am willing to bet I can create a very inefficient software stack that yields a higher power profile despite there being less silicon.

Message.Title: Jen-Hsun Huang : "We respect the intellectual property of others."
Message.Msg: From Nvidia's "Our Code". In excerpts. Our Code : Creating a Principled Workplace "The bedrock of our culture is impeccable integrity." This is the expectation that each of us operates at the highest ethical standard. It’s important for you to familiarize yourself with Our Code, which sets out the standards guiding our professional relationships. It describes the principles that apply to how we act toward customers, COMPETITORS, partners, vendors, government regulators, stockholders, fellow employees, as well as the community at large. These standards... will help determine our future. In everything we do, we must act honestly, ethically, fairly, legally, and in a manner in which all of NVIDIA can take pride. We don’t do this simply because we’d get in trouble if we didn’t. We do it because honest and ethical dealings have been, and will remain, fundamental to our long-term success. Our Code forms the basis of our culture and what it means to be part of NVIDIA. It’s a great privilege for me to build this amazing company with you. Jen-Hsun Huang Co-Founder and CEO "Respecting Intellectual Property." As a technology company, our lifeblood is intellectual property: patents, copyrights, trade secrets, and trademarks. If we want others to respect our intellectual property, we must do the same in return. We respect the intellectual property of others. When we use patents and copyrighted material belonging to others, we obtain the proper licenses and permissions. When we cite the trademarks of others, we use them in accordance with the guidelines provided by the owners. We do not use NVIDIA networks, computers, or other resources to acquire, share, or store copyrighted material that is not properly licensed." A nice looking little brochure, right boys? It sure is nice looking. And ya gotta just Love that part about, "In everything we do, we must act honestly, ethically, fairly, legally, and in a manner in which all of NVIDIA can take pride." "We respect the intellectual property of others."

Topic.Title: Jen-Hsun Huang : "We respect the intellectual property of others."

Message.Msg: "We respect the intellectual property of others." The key adjective here seems to be 'intellectual'...so is that reason nobody 'respects' you?

If we want others to respect our intellectual property, we must do the same in return. We respect the intellectual property of others. "If we want others to respect our intellectual property, we must do the same in return. We respect the intellectual property of others."

Topic.Title: What is Icera i500 “soft” modem or in long form, a Software Defined Radio (SDR)?

Message.Msg: A SDR has to be better designed to save on power. It very likely reduces the die area (which is reduces the cost of production) and enables field fixes and upgrades. From a power standpoint, it's best to have an optimized, hard-wired implementation of each radio and modem and power gate (turn off) all but the one in use at the time. But this design strategy can't be used in the real world because of bugs, evolving standards and improved understanding of operating conditions. If you add enough hooks and programmability in a hard-wired design to allow fixes, it's likely to end up less efficient than a SDR. If Icera has enough right that the i500 works, it's a big step forward for the industry. Every new design will be a SDR.

Message.Title: Tegra 4 to be in LG produced Nexus 5 Phone and LG produced Nexus 7.7 Tablet
Message.Msg: It looks like after what appears to be a successful Nexus 4 partnership, hardware-maker LG will once again partner up with the Android OS-maker to deliver two new Nexus products, the Nexus 5 smartphone and a Nexus 7.7 tablet. Nexus 5.5 Smartphone The LG-made Nexus 5 is rumored to debut with a 5-inch display, and not the 5.5-inch full HD panel that LG’s been rumored to sport on its new Optimus G2 phone arriving sometime this year. The Nexus 5, like the HTC Droid DNA, would have a full 1080p HD panel on its 5-inch display. The phone would use NVIDIA’s Tegra 4 processor and have 2 GB of RAM and a 13-megapixel camera. It’s unclear if this camera module is the same 13-megapixel sensor that’s found on the international and Sprint version of the current Optimus G, or if it’s a newer Sony Exmor sensor that will debut on the Sony Xperia Z smartphone. Like today’s Nexus 4, the Nexus 5′s 8 GB model is said to debut at $299, making it an affordable option given that it requires no contract or carrier subsidies. Nexus 7.7 Tablet Additionally, it looks like LG may have won the tablet bid with the next generation of Nexus tablets, replacing Asus on the current Nexus 7 with a Nexus 7.7 model. The Nexus 7.7 will have a high resolution 1920 X 1200-pixel display with a 294 ppi, according to Phone Arena. With a 7.7-inch panel the Nexus tablet will be inching closer to Apple’s heavily marketed iPad mini with a 7.9-inch display. The Nexus 7.7 will use the Tegra 4 CPU from NVIDIA and will start with 8 GB of storage. The slate will also have front-facing and rear-facing cameras, though the exact specs are unknown. If in fact early development of Key Lime Pie was centered around the NVIDIA Tegra 4 chipset, as the new Nexus 5 and Nexus 7.7 suggest, it would be a huge win for NVIDIA as the last time its chipset was the center of Google’s Android development was on the Motorola Xoom, which used the Tegra 2 dual-core CPU. LG LG has announced its aggressive turnaround plan to be more competitive in the phone market with plans to ship 75 million phones, of which 45 million will be smartphones. Its partnership with Google for the Nexus 4 had helped to increase the visibility of LG as a phone-maker and the continued partnership will likely help to benefit LG.

Message.Title: 12:54 PM LG and Google (GOOG) are reportedly working on a new Nexus phone.The device is said to feature Nvidia's (NVDA) new Tegra 4 processor
Message.Msg: 12:54 PM LG and Google (GOOG) are reportedly working on a new Nexus phone, one that could be a decent high-end entry. The device is said to feature Nvidia's (NVDA) new Tegra 4 processor, a 5" 1080p display (standard for the latest high-end Android models), and a 13MP camera. Also reportedly in the pipeline is a Nexus 7.7 tablet with a Tegra 4 and 1920x1200 display. Google's Nexus 7 tablet has sold pretty well, but sales of the Nexus 4 phone (also a Google/L2G collaboration) has been hurt by limited availability and a lack of 4G support.

Message.Title: Grey T4, Fools take
Message.Msg: FOOLS: hope you enjoy this excerpt, which examines at five key catalysts facing the company. Integrated graphics performance: There will always be a market for discrete GPUs among serious gamers and enthusiasts. However, integrated graphics remains a threat. For example, Intel's (NASDAQ: INTC ) latest Ivy Bridge chips have seen graphics performance up to 41% better than the previous generation Sandy Bridge processors. AMD's (NYSE: AMD ) Llano processors outperform Ivy Bridge by 33%. The threat that these CPUs pose is commensurate with their improvements in integrated graphics performance. Tegra "Grey" release: The launch of a Tegra chip with integrated LTE will be a momentous occasion for NVIDIA, one that will give the company a new level of legitimacy in challenging Qualcomm's (NASDAQ: QCOM ) dominant lead in the market. In some cases, NVIDIA has been forced to split design wins (like the HTC One X) with Qualcomm when OEMs want integrated LTE variants for certain markets. With "Grey," NVIDIA could potentially score those spots exclusively. Competition with Intel: NVIDIA and Intel historically sold complementary products, but rivalry between the two will only increase in the future. In January 2011, NVIDIA scored a six-year cross-licensing agreement with Intel, earning it $1.5 billion in licensing fees payable in five annual installments. However, the two companies will see competition intensify in supercomputers, mobile applications processors, and baseband modems. PC market: As NVIDIA's largest segment, GPU sales into the PC market remain incredibly important to the company's overall results. If growing Tegra sales merely offset GPU declines, the net result may be little to no sales growth. NVIDIA is intent on diversifying away from the PC market and into mobile devices, but this transition is still a work in progress. Tegra tablet wins: The tablet market is ripe with growth, and NVIDIA is set to capitalize on the non-iPad segment. Important wins like the Nexus 7 and Surface RT are just the beginning. There will be an entire wave of Tegra-powered Windows RT devices and new Android tablets in the near future.
